name: Acoustic alt.folk jam session Meetup [London Southeast Lewisham]

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
Acoustic Alt.folk Meetup [London Southeast]

Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON SE6 2JT [nearest station Catford/Catford Bridge; Buses 181/284 from Lewisham station stop X directly adjacent)

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country with neo-trad interpretations and original music. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly.

This is a session for all attending to join in. We have a mix of experience, from performing solo musicians open to working beyond their own solo path, those developing confidence to perform folk and acoustic music to those getting into ensemble, session and band experience to grow their improvisation and aural playing. Everyone joins in, singer, background vocals, even tambourine, percussion. We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments. Local cafe audience present for feedback.

Sign up RSVP for musicians.

name: London Southeast [Lewisham] Acoustic Indie Session Musicians Meet Up

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
\*\*\*We're taking a break over summer! Most of our musician friends are travelling and recovering from being grounded so we will only be doing a few closed jam sessions and rehearsals in The Film Atelier! Back soon!\*\*\*

We're a group of local London southeast musicians/singers/songwriters who meet for an acoustic session on Saturday 5pms.

Instruments: Vocalists, acoustic/electric guitarists (limits on how many per session); mandolin, flute, cajon, bass (electric), cello, fiddles, bodhran, harp join in the mix.

What we are not: - we are not an Open Mic. Funk, R'nB', electronica, hip hop, soul and commercial music isn't what we do.

What we do at events: - we are a mix of singer-songwriters, musicians, band players on the gig circuit and/or open mic'g. We prefer acoustic, indie, folk repertoire. We support one another: jamming experience, singing in the spotlight in front of peers, getting to know each other in a small regular session meet.

How long? - 2 hours. Acoustic music sessions limited to a max of 8 musicians.

Where? We aren't going to post our private venue address online to get gatecrashed by drum n bass types! We are in the London borough of Lewisham with reasonable transport links and parking in the area.. Those interested - PM for details.

name: Extraordinary Narratives:  Stories & Songs from the 'Convivencia' [Co-Existence]

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
Local Lewisham resident **Sef**, and specialist composer on the 2 string fiddle called the erhu, **Li Cheong**, will sing, play and perform the re-telling of the extra-ordinary time when Christians, Jews and Muslims lived in harmony in Islamic Spain until the expulsion of Jews and Muslims in the year 1492 A.D.

**Convivencia** \~ *Co-existence* \~ describes this period of special harmony among diverse people.

Li Cheong is a composer and performer of the chinese 2 string fiddle erhu. Growing up in Hong Kong, he loves exploring music from divergent cultures and is particularly drawn towards Middle Eastern and Indian classical music.

Sef Townsend is a imaginative storyteller who employs song and story in the retelling of our humanity.

Both have performed internationally in music and storytelling festivals and intercultural vents across Portugal, Cyprus, Italy, South America, The Far East. Their most recent performance took place at The Marrakech International Storytelling Festival and it is with great pleasure we welcome Sef & Li Cheong to THE FILM ATELIER.

[Children: Free Entry. Adults: £1.00
All donations go to the performing artists]

name: TOM SMITH Classical Guitar/Composer in CONCERT @THE FILM ATELIER LONDON SE6

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
THE FILM ATELIER is pleased to present an evening of inventive classical guitar music with electronic compositions.

**Tom Smith**, classical guitar player and composer, draws on invention with electronics, idiomatic scores and improvisation.   A graduate {Masters in Music Performance] from Goldsmiths College, University of London, he studied guitar with Laura Snowden completing his final recital integrating works spanning the Renaissance era lute towards contemporary compositions of the past decade.
 
His repertoire has attained the Griffin Prize for Music following his Bachelors degree at Brunel University; recent film performances for *Sarah Belle Reid’s Postcard Project* and *The Gloves Are Off*, a fundraiser for *The Creative Passport* endeavour.  
 
His recent compositions have received BBC radio airplay and featured on the *Stationary Travels* blog.  Tom currently performs with The London Mandolin Quartet.
 
*Etiquette: Concert starts 7.00pm followed by informal Q&A and coffeehouse social after the concert with the artist. We encourage live acoustic music for community well-being and welcome respectful attendance. **Mobile Phones off.**  Under-18s welcome. Non-alcohol family friendly environment. Seat Reservation possible in advance via email or drop into The Film Atelier, 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT.*

There are some spaces allocated to the Meetup.com forum.
Email: the [masked]

Under 18s, children (supervised) and well-behaved pets welcome. We are an intimate small venue: please reserve a seat if you have standing difficulties.

description:

Bus Routes: 181 or 284 Bus Stop X
Driving: The cafe is conveniently located OUTSIDE of ULEZ. Stay outside of the South Circular Road to avoid the ULEZ and park anywhere south of Sangley Road [yellow lines and dropped kerbs not permitted obviously]. There is easy parking access to the venue and an unloading bay right beside the side street, Inchmery Road.

name: Falling Moon @ THE FILM ATELIER:  Hymnals & Acoustic Folk

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
Falling Moon Productions brings some fresh talent to THE FILM ATELIER 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT on Thursday 23rd JUNE 2022 @7pm onwards!

THE FILM ATELIER hosts another night of folk & alternative music!
A wonderful lineup consisting of ***Hobby Horse***, who will bring the hymns and the acoustic bliss, ***Cat Rin***, whose virtuosic keyboard playing and Welsh singing will be a delight to the senses, and ***Frankie D***, who will attempt to convey some sort of meaning through poetic songwriting and intense vulnerability.

*Falling Moon is a new music promotion and event organisation thing. Follow @_fallingmoon on Instagram to keep up to date with everything and do not hesitate to get in touch if you wish to be involved.*

======================================================================

**THE FILM ATELIER 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT** is unusual as London's only dedicated acoustic coffeehouse lounge venue serving high altitude organic (that's low caffeine) ice cold Peruvian indigenous coffee and fresh Peruvian pomegranate cold hand-pressed juice as well as our range of herbal tisane teas and fluffy Japanese Dorayaki dessert pancake filled with green matcha, mascarpone, chocolate ganache and select red bean.

By day, it is both a speciaist cafe and teahouse; a psychotherapy & counselling speciality therapy space for engaging with mental health challenges using Cognitive Analytic Therapy [CAT] and accredited clinical evidence based practices and a traditional film camera darkroom photography specialist studio, darkroom and chill out space for creatives eschewing digital interference in everyday life.

We're encouraging under 18s; families; well-behaved pets to attend and enjoy acoustic folk evenings of music like we used to! Tonight, three acoustic folk artists perform followed by a late evening social in our therapy garden yard sanctuary or intimate studio.

FREE ENTRY ON RSVP via Meet-up or email.

Closest trains: Catford, Catford Bridge, Hither Green stations.
Buses 181 or 284 from Lewisham station to Stop X directly outside THE FILM ATELIER
Car: Stay south of the A205 South Circular Road for ULEZ free. Also free parking in side streets.

name: Acoustic alt.folk jam session Meetup [THE FILM ATELIER LONDON SE6 2JT]

description:
Acoustic Alt.folk Meetup [London Southeast]

We've started a Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in Lewisham [London Southeast] at our venue space, THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON, SE6 2JT in southeast London at the start of the year and have been holding public jam sessions in our acoustic coffeehouse venue.

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country like Gregory Alan Isakov whom we aspire to (and fail miserably) and other alternative folk genres. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly

We have a mix of experience, from solo performing, band performance to open mics and those starting out playing ensemble. Everyone joins in, singer, background vocals, even tambourine, percussion. We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments.

We play in the acoustic lounge of The Film Atelier behind the CAT Cafe where audience members sit and listen.

RSVP to sign up for session.

name: THE FILM ATELIER presents:  Acoustic Folk Singer Songwriter RITA TAM concert gig

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
THE FILM ATELIER is pleased to present an evening with intimate and inspirational acoustic folk singer-songwriter **RITA TAM**. Acoustic coffeehouse concert followed by social meet and mix with the artist after the concert over non-alcohol tisane French teas; cold pressed Peruvian pomegranate juice and herbal house tea with Japanese dorayaki dessert pancakes.

Rita has released two albums and dwells in our neighbouring London Southeast quarters. We're pleased to welcome Rita back to THE FILM ATELIER for another personal concert of vulnerably human songs of hope and light beyond the everday.

**Etiquette:**

Respectful Entry Free via RSVP here or via email:
**[masked]**

Under 18s, children (supervised) and well-behaved pets welcome. We are an intimate small venue: please reserve a seat if you have standing difficulties.

Mobile phones on silent: doors closed during songs: late arrivals - please wait for end of song before entry.

name: Acoustic alt.folk jam session Meetup [THE FILM ATELIER LONDON SE6 2JT]

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
Acoustic Alt.folk Meetup [London Southeast]

We've started a Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in Lewisham [London Southeast] at our venue space, THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON, SE6 2JT in southeast London at the start of the year and have been holding public jam sessions in our acoustic coffeehouse venue.

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country like Gregory Alan Isakov whom we aspire to (and fail miserably) and other alternative folk genres. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly

We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments.

We play in the acoustic lounge of The Film Atelier behind the CAT Cafe where audience members sit and listen.

RSVP to sign up for session.

name: World Music [Ethnic Singers/Instrumentalists] London Jam Session Meet-Up!

description:

name: London Classical Chamber Musicians Meet-Up @THE FILM ATELIER SE6 2JT

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
Classical Music & Chamber Music Meet-up: London Southeast [London Borough of Lewisham]

**Venue: THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT (acoustic lounge/ CAT CAFE)**

We're a friendly group of local classical musicians who meet to jam informally. If you like classical music and know your way around a classical instrument and want to meet up to play with others, come alone! We work out beforehand, what repertoire parts of scores the sign-up members can play & share music spanning medieval, renaissance, modern and contemporary - all players welcome to recommend their own repertoire.

Bring your own instrument. Recorders, brass, woodwind, classical guitar, string instruments welcome. We don't have a piano sorry (!)

[Max. = 8 instrumental players] All ages welcome. Under 18s require parental consent and independent/own travel arrangements. Please note the session happens live in the workshop with the adjacent cafe area open for the public and audience. We rehearse and perform indoors. Outdoor garden cafe open for good weather.

name: THE FILM ATELIER ~ Spoken word stand-up artists (supported by musical chorus)

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
**Now inviting spoken word artists and improvisational musicians to [TheFilm Atelier](https://www.facebook.com/FilmAtelierSE6?__cft__%5B0%5D=AZV2DazrrMi6cljojY9oEHHZIQs-L5gjAqXN4QLCrVRzelThdX_f-n7n2cqhaOTc-KNNQZ_428WpJUhO0_nrfKavXtrSoq8jg2LYl12aWSZFZQ&__tn__=-%5DK-R) 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT**

**Thursday 12th May 2022 @6.30pm**

**Open Mic Spoken Word/Stand-up artists - to be accompanied by musical chorus in dialogue and response.**

**Invitations for applications to perform spoken word, poetry, readings and commentaries, diary notes from the pandemic; on loss and grief, or life in general.**

**We invite musicians to apply and join spoken word performers on stage to listen and support spoken word artists with a musical chorus and dialogue and response.**

**THE BRIEF:**
**Applicants for spoken word performances**
**Email: [[masked]](mailto:[masked]) [Mark subject title clearly]**

Interested musicians can join our house musicians.

**Subject: 10 minute verbal performances. We value dialogue on life; lived experience, enduring challenges with society; struggles with mental health, personal experience, struggles and challenges; comedy, humour and parody – but not at the expense of others.**

**Followed by acoustic folk concert 7.30pm - 9.00pm with Noah Smith & Mystery Performer**

name: SPOKEN WORD POETRY STAND-UP COMEDY SET TO MUSIC @THE FILM ATELIER

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
You are invited to speak; stand-up comedy, observe, muse; prepare a poem; a letter - of love, of loss; of struggles, or even a complaint letter to your council for emptying the rubbish; a shopping list -, stand up comedy, observations - anything!

Our musicians listen and perform with you at the same time to lift your spoken word to a new level of interpretation. Sign-up required in advance.

All spoken word artists are invited to submit a short commentary on their material for speaking for the evening. This is a fun night of speaking with a microphone to "voice yourself". If you're shy - you are welcome to do it in pairs!

Musicians here can also join our house musicians to create an interesting dialogue between spoken word performance and music with a chorus.

We respect everyone and we mean it: humour does not marginalise nor target others; voicing is cathartic and the creative arts of performing pathos and evacuating struggles for witnessing is a healing act in a safe audience. We invite you to be that safe audience for others too.

name: London Chinese Traditional Music Chamber Meet-Up

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
4. London Chinese Music Ensemble Meet up:

Do you sing in Cantonese, Mandarin or play a chinese instrument like an erhu, guzheng,pipa, liuqin, bawu, dizi or suona?

Meet up for our friends in London who play a chinese musical instrument and are familiar with classical chinese folk repertoire: some knowledge of the chinese written music system is required.

The music ensemble regularly meet and perform in concert and follow the annual festivals and its associated music. If you aren't sure of your standard, drop a note. We have some links to chinese music instrument tutors in London. We meet as a group with a few spaces for new members only.

name: THE FILM ATELIER SE6 presents an evening of classical guitar: Stelios Kyriakidis

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
Venue: **THE FILM ATELIER 314 SANGLEY ROAD LONDON SE6 2JT**

Date: **Thursday 5th May 2022 @18.30h**

Artist: **Stelios Kyriakidis** (Mr)

Instrument: **Classical Nylon Guitar**

THE FILM ATELIER is pleased to welcome Stelios back to the London southeast! A graduate with a Masters Degree (Music in Performance) with classical guitar from Trinity Laban, he promises to delight our intimate acoustic cafe lounge with original and hypnotic guitar playing.

Over the years he has performed extensively worldwide in the USA, Europe and across the UK with the release of two EPs and two Singles of his own original composition for solo classical guitar in showcase venues such as the *21st Century Guitar Conference*, Indianapolis, USA; *Handmade & Recycled Festival*, Athens, Greece. In the UK he has graced the *London Contemporary Art Fair*, the *Robin Howard Theatre*, the *Green*
*Street Festival* London and *King's Place,* London. In his home of Greece he has performed at the *Arion Academy Guitar Festival*. Three of his compositions have been published by the UCLA library (USA).

His debut *Small Primal Voices*, his debut in 2017, was described by *Musician magazine* as *“an EP of hypnotic pieces and well-received soundtracks using just his guitar”*. *Optica* followed in
September 2020, stating that *“Kyriakidis has a delightful way of creating bright, shimmering melodies that you want to hear again”*.

Reviews lauded *A Moment and A Thousand Years*, released in 2021 as a series of solo guitar compositions during the pandemic lockdown era as “the piece exhibits finest playing skills along with a musicality
that is glowing with talent, intent and a deep understanding of universal beauty” (Music Dances When You Sleep).

\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-

This is an open house event at our intimate acoustic lounge cafe. Doors close for entry at 19.00h prompt for respectful attendance by patrons and open during intervals.

This not a ticketed event however RSVP since seating numbers are limited to 30.

There is no entry fee: donations direct to the artist are possible.

Under 18s welcome (parental consent).

description:

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

description:
4. London Chinese Music Ensemble Meet up:

Do you play a chinese instrument like an erhu, guzheng,pipa, liuqin, bawu, dizi or suona?

This is a meet up for our friends in London who play a chinese musical instrument and are familiar with classical chinese folk repertoire: some knowledge of the chinese written music system is required.

The music ensemble regularly meet and perform in concert and follow the annual festivals and its associated music. If you aren't sure of your standard, drop a note. We have some links to chinese music instrument tutors in London.

Bring your instrument and play. Venue in the London Borough of Lewisham - RSVP only. We have our own house guzheng and other less portable instruments.

Midweek Walk: Tring, Grand Union Canal and Reservoirs
description:
Being relatively new to this malarkey, I have volunteered to lead a walk in Martin’s absence. The only walk I feel confident in leading relates to Tring’s canal paths and reservoirs, both of great beauty and wildlife interest. 
After meeting in the centre of Tring at the Forge Car Park, my aim is to minimize walking through the urban sprawl as best I can. 
We leave from the car park through quaint alleyways, entering the charm of Spider Park, continuing past the back of the picturesque houses that form Rosebery Way and Kingsley Walk. Next we will encounter the hedonistic delights of Old Joe’s Wood, before crossing the Icknield Way towards Little Tring. Soon, after a brief hike through a short overgrown pathway, we will be in open country accompanied by gentle sheep and cows. A slightly undulating hike will take us towards the village of Wilstone crossing the Wendover Arm of the canal, skirting the reservoir and passing through this lovely village, where we join the Aylesbury Arm of the Grand Union Canal. Here we follow the canal eastwards, passing close by to Marsworth and then skirting Startops reservoir. 
Following the canal path towards Bulbourne, we have have a decision to make ….. turn right and follow the Wendover Arm back towards Tring (past Heygates) or continue on ( past the Grand Junction ) and to return to Tring, via Marshcroft Lane (perhaps, Martin, an experienced leader would decide in advance!!). 
On arriving back at the car park in Tring, we have another decision to make …. Mimi’s (not dog friendly) or The Robin Hood (very dog friendly). 
Hope you will support me on my debut and please be gentle with me if I c\*\*k up!!

Rex Review:
Hollywood’s evergreen leading lady, Sandra Bullock, cuts a despondent figure as a troubled romance-novel writer who’s stuck in a rut.
Trotting gamely by her side like a panting Labrador puppy with abs is Channing Tatum, playing the popular model who’s graced most of her book covers, mostly shirtless. The latest entry in her series about globetrotting lovers isn’t selling so well, given that it reads like a eulogy with sex scenes; its details about an ancient civilization in South America, however, have attracted the interest of Daniel Radcliffe’s evil, cheerful billionaire. He thinks she knows where a hidden treasure is and, one abduction later, Bullock’s reluctant Indiana Jones in a magenta sequined catsuit is clomping around the deep jungle. Tatum’s dim-witted himbo, who harbours a schoolboy crush for the wordsmith, is determined to rescue her.
The next hour is a hilarious procession of flying fists, trashed charcuterie buffets and a scene-stealing cameo by a tousled Brad Pitt. The Lost City has a genuine buoyancy that is hard to resist. Most comedies are afraid to go big, but this one most definitely does.

Trailer:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nfKO9rYDmE8

Parking in Berkhamsted is very difficult but there is road parking along Three Close Lane. Please allow time to find somewhere to park. We meet on (or near to) the sofa by the bar.

name: Midweek Walk: Iron Age Fort Walk, Cholesbury
description:
This is a mainly flat walk 5.2 mile walk through fields and woodland which shouldn't take much more than 2 hours. Cholesbury is an ancient hilltop village situated in the Chiltern Hills which are officially designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The area is criss-crossed with footpaths and bridleways and additional routes for riders have recently been created. It is rich in wildlife, birds and butterflies. The beechwoods, bluebells and orchids all add to the great diversity of life to be found here.
Cholesbury Camp is one of the best preserved examples of an Iron Age hill fort and is one of the most impressive prehistoric settlements in the Chilterns. It was probably constructed in the Middle Iron Age [masked]BC) and occupied until soon after the Roman invasion in 50AD.
Walkers are welcome at the Full Moon pub where there is a beer garden with a view of the nearby 19th century windmill.
https://www.fullmoonpub.info

It is best to park opposite the pub alongside the road.

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. Please be sure to make me aware if you have any medical conditions.

Dogs are welcome as always but please be mindful to keep them on leads for roads and around other animals.

If you are unable to attend please be sure to change your RSVP otherwise our departure will be delayed. My contact number is[masked].

name: Evening Walk and Drinks: Chipperfield to Flaunden circular walk
description:

We can meet in the little car park in front of the church but there are other parking spots around the Common. The address for the local cafe is 10 The Common, Chipperfield, Kings Langley WD4 9BS which is just past the church.
What3words location... tops.piper.outer

This is a 5.4 mile walk which should take not much more than 2 hours. We head out to the north-west of Chipperfield and through farmland before picking up the Chiltern Way in Hogpits Bottom. We head for Flaunden before cutting back across farmland. Skirting Rosehall Wood, we cross farmland to the west of Commonwood then duck back through the woods on Chipperfield Common.

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. name: Berk worms 2022 🐛 BookClub: Psychological Thriller month
description:
For July 2022, we have selected to read a thriller entitled ‘Then She Vanishes’ by Claire Douglas. The book length runs at approximately 399 pages. It is available in all formats. The kindle edition is £4.99.

About the book:

Heather's sister Flora vanished. The night that lies tore their friendship apart.

But years later, when a brutal double murder shakes their childhood town, Jess returns home.

Because the suspect is Heather.

What happened to the girl you used to know?

About the Author:

Claire Douglas has worked as a journalist for fifteen years, writing features for women's magazines and newspapers, but she's dreamed of being a novelist since the age of seven. She finally got her wish after winning Marie Claire's Debut Novel Award for her first book, The Sisters, which became a bestseller. She is the award winning author of seven stand alone thrillers, THE SISTERS, LOCAL GIRL MISSING, LAST SEEN ALIVE, DO NOT DISTURB, THEN SHE VANISHES, JUST LIKE THE OTHER GIRLS and her most recent, THE COUPLE AT NO. 9, which is a number one Amazon bestseller and reached number three on the Sunday Times bestsellers list. Her books have sold over 500,000 copies in the UK and have been translated into twenty languages.

You can find Claire on Twitter at @DougieClaire, Instagram as clairedouglasauthor, or visit her Facebook page clairedouglasauthor. She lives in Bath, England, with her husband and two children.

__________________________________

Critical views:

‘A riveting, edge-of-your-seat excitement fest - the plotting was so sinfully clever that I was kept endlessly guessing' 5***** Reader Review

“If you are a fan of suspense, twists and more twists, Then She Vanishes should be right up your alley."--BookPage

name: Midweek Walk: Iron Age Fort Walk, Cholesbury
description:
This is a mainly flat walk 5.2 mile walk through fields and woodland which shouldn't take much more than 2 hours. Cholesbury is an ancient hilltop village situated in the Chiltern Hills which are officially designated as an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. The area is criss-crossed with footpaths and bridleways and additional routes for riders have recently been created. It is rich in wildlife, birds and butterflies. The beechwoods, bluebells and orchids all add to the great diversity of life to be found here.
Cholesbury Camp is one of the best preserved examples of an Iron Age hill fort and is one of the most impressive prehistoric settlements in the Chilterns. It was probably constructed in the Middle Iron Age [masked]BC) and occupied until soon after the Roman invasion in 50AD.
Walkers are welcome at the Full Moon pub where there is a beer garden with a view of the nearby 19th century windmill.
https://www.fullmoonpub.info

It is best to park opposite the pub alongside the road.

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. Please be sure to make me aware if you have any medical conditions.

Dogs are welcome as always but please be mindful to keep them on leads for roads and around other animals.

name: Midweek Walk: Misbourne Valley and Old Amersham
description:
Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. Please be sure to make me aware if you have any medical conditions.

Dogs are welcome as always but please be mindful to keep them on leads for roads and around other animals.

If you are unable to attend please be sure to change your RSVP otherwise our departure will be delayed. My contact number is[masked].

The Misbourne is a modern success story and a testament to the efforts of campaigners to rescue it. A natural chalk stream, water companies were attracted to its exceptionally pure water and by the 1990s it was one of the worst affected rivers in the country for abstraction. A new pipeline was built from more sustainable sources and the river was rescued, and this circular walk gives you the opportunity to enjoy a stretch of it, as well as the delights of Old Amersham. It begins in the town, but soon heads up the side of the valley cut by the river to afford great views, although there is a climb involved first to earn them. The river itself is your companion for much of the second half of the walk, and includes a delightful stopping point by a ford, great for picnics or a paddle. At the walk's end there's the opportunity to take in a monument to seven Protestant martyrs burned at the stake in the 16th century, as well as the opportunity to sample part of Old Amersham. Here you can see the King's Arms, which featured as The Lucky Boatman in the film 'Four Weddings and a Funeral', as well as a number of historical buildings. Allow a couple of hours for this five and half mile walk.

After the walk, we can visit the Saracens Head pub which is very welcoming and serves well-priced food.

We can meet in the Old Amersham car park, the post code is HP7 0UT. For those using What3words, solar.forest.cards .

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. name: Evening Walk and Drinks: Aldbury, Aldbury Nowers and Ashridge
description:
This is an evening walk to enable members who are working during the day to join us. We should finish in ample time to enjoy the hospitality at the Greyhound Inn.
This 5.4 mile walk takes us through rolling wooded countryside and steep chalk grassland. The walk follows typical Chiltern sunken lanes that criss-cross the area. The walk begins in the picturesque village of Aldbury. There is some parking space in front of the Greyhound pub and around the pond but another option is in the car park further along Stocks Road. We walk uphill through the Stocks golf club and into the woods to pick up the Ridgeway where there is one steep climb to Aldbury Nowers which is a biological Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) managed by the Hertfordshire and Middlesex Wildlife Trust. We continue across open countryside towards Ivinghoe Beacon but cut back to walk uphill towards the Ashridge estate woodland and along Duncombe Terrace. At the Bridgewater Monument we head downhill to return to Aldbury.
The walk should take less than 2.5 hours and once we return to Aldbury, there is the option to take refreshments in the Greyhound where there is a spacious beer garden.
The address for the pub is The Greyhound, Stocks Road, Aldbury, Nr Tring. Hertfordshire, HP23 5RT.
Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. Rex Review:
The need for speed is back. Decades on, the heart-pounding sequel finally soars onto screen.
30 years after the events of the original, Maverick has been constantly dodging promotion so he can do what he loves most; fly planes. He’s about to be grounded for good when he’s sent back to Top Gun to train a group of pilots for a top-secret mission that will be the ultimate test of their skills. Little does he know, it will also be an exercise that allows him to put his past to rest.
You have to hand it to Tom Cruise. Who else could anchor a bigger, brighter blockbuster than this? Creating a worthy sequel to a near-legendary film can be a minefield. And when that movie was released over a generation ago, the stakes are even higher. White-knuckle from beginning to end, Maverick pulls it off in every way imaginable.
Follow-ups are a regular part of our cinematic diet, but this is a real game-changer. Like its pilots, and especially their leader, Top Gun: Maverick has joined the elite. This is how it’s done.

Trailer:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qSqVVswa420

Parking in Berkhamsted is very difficult but there is road parking along Three Close Lane. Please allow time to find somewhere to park. We meet on (or near to) the sofa by the bar.

name: Midweek Walk: Four Reservoirs
description:
The walk begins with a flight of locks along the Grand Union Canal, before heading down a stretch of the partially restored Wendover Arm of that canal. The route then diverts into open countryside before regaling the walker with a magnificent view of the large Wilstone Reservoir, one of four on this walk. Here, there this an option to enter a bird hide to view the many species who call this water their home at different times of the year. The other reservoirs follow, making this a relaxing 5.4 miles of relatively easy walking following a circular route. Allow a good couple of hours to complete the walk, longer if you want to linger.
The walk starts at Startops Reservoir, which is clearly signposted as one of the Marsworth Reservoirs on the B489 linking the A41 to the north east of Aston Clinton and Linslade. Marsworth lies in a little remnant of Hertfordshire to the north of Tring, and can also be reached using the Wingrave Road out of the town off the B488. Use the postcode HP23 4LJ, which is also the location of the lovely little Waters Edge cafe by the side of the canal just off the main car park. We can go to the tearoom after the walk for a snack and chat.
The car park does carry a charge with funds used to maintain the reservoirs.

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. The Bovingdon Players’ ever-popular Murder Mystery evenings return with “Who Killed Rob Cockyn?” on June 17th and 18th 2022.
Bring along your own food and drink (and something to eat them with) to enjoy at your table, while you watch the drama unfold, and then try and solve the mystery! You will even have a chance to question the suspects, who all seem very ﬁshy…
The scenario: Rob Cockyn is in serious ﬁnancial trouble. His chain of ﬁsh and chip restaurants, largely ﬁnanced by loans from business associates and an ex-lover, is facing bankruptcy. Rob has been forced to call a creditors’ meeting. But has he had his chips? Will it ﬂounder? Are all the ﬁsh puns just red herrings?

Rex Review:
The follow-up to the 2019 film adaptation of the period phenomenon was originally planned for Christmas. After what must have felt like a gruelling wait, the new era is finally upon us.
Julian Fellowes is back on board as curator, and he had the following to say: "It really is a new era. The further the ’20s went along, the more the world was changing in so many ways. Everything from entertainment to transport was really different by the end of the ’20s. As we know from the last film, Mary may not be the titular head of the household, but she is effectively running the show. We take that further. We’re trying to mark the change — the fact that Crawleys of Downton are nearly in the 1930s, which is merely the beginning of the modern world."
The first film featured the Crawley family receiving a visit by the King and Queen to their family estate. There were plenty of questions left over that need to be addressed too: How is Mary handling the responsibility of managing the Crawley estate? Did Lady Edith Crawley safely deliver her child? Downton fans won’t be disappointed.

Trailer:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wN0Spmq610Q

name: Berk worms 2022 🐛 BookClub: Historical Fiction
description:
For June 2022, we have selected to read a Historical fiction novel entitled ‘The Burning🔥 Chambers’ by Kate Mosse first published in 2018. There is also a sequel to this book called ‘The City of Tears’. The book length runs at approximately 600 pages so it is best to get started as soon as you sign up! It is available in most formats, including paperback. The kindle edition is £4.99. I picked up my copy at a second hand book shop so they are about.

About the book:

Transporting readers to sixteenth-century Languedoc where, against a backdrop of simmering sectarian tensions, nineteen-year-old Minou receives a mysterious message at her father’s bookshop. A host of interesting characters and varying settings.

Carcassonne 1562. Nineteen-year-old Minou Joubert receives an anonymous letter at her father’s bookshop. Sealed with a distinctive family crest, it contains just five words: SHE KNOWS THAT YOU LIVE.

But before Minou can decipher the mysterious message, a chance encounter with a young Huguenot convert, Piet Reydon, changes her destiny forever. For Piet has a dangerous mission of his own, and he will need Minou’s help if he is to get out of La Cité alive . . .

A thrilling adventure and a heartbreaking love story, The Burning Chambers is a historical novel of excitement, conspiracy and danger like no other . .

About the Author:

Kate Mosse is an award-winning novelist, playwright, essayist and non-fiction writer, the author of nine novels and short-story collections, including the multimillion-selling Languedoc Trilogy, The Burning Chambers Series and number one bestselling Gothic fiction The Winter Ghosts and The Taxidermist’s Daughter. Her books have been translated into thirty-seven languages and published in more than forty countries. The Founder Director of the Women’s Prize for Fiction, she is the Founder of the global Woman In History campaign. A Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, Kate is a Visiting Professor of Contemporary Fiction and Creative Writing at the University of Chichester.

__________________________________

Critical views:

‘A powerful storyteller with an abundant imagination.’ ― Daily Telegraph

‘Impressively bold and ambitious, it features betrayals, broken friendship, family secrets and the horrors of fanaticism. Fans will love it.’― Daily Mail

‘Transporting readers to sixteenth-century Languedoc where, against a backdrop of simmering sectarian tensions, nineteen-year-old Minou receives a mysterious message at her father’s bookshop. Gripping, complex and intensely atmospheric.’ ― Mail on Sunday

‘The Burning Chambers is a tour de force, a compelling adventure that views the past with insight, compassion and humour, and reminds us of the variety of women’s voices so often forgotten in the official accounts.’ ― Observer

name: Midweek Walk: Four reservoirs, Wilstone
description:
Please read all of the instructions.

This is 6.2 miles of relatively easy walking following a circular route. We meet at Wilstone Reservoir car park (HP23 4NW) which is along the B489 just after the PE Mead Farm Shop. After the walk we can visit the new Farm Shop cafe which has an outside are we can use.

The walk begins with a magnificent view of the large Wilstone Reservoir, one of four on this walk. We walk around the Startops, Tringford and Marsworth Reservoirs before picking up the Grand Union Canal passing a flight of locks along the Grand Union Canal. Then we head down a stretch of the partially restored Wendover Arm of that canal. At Little Tring, we pick up the Outer Aylesbury Ring before returning to Wilstone Reservoir. Here, there this an option to enter a bird hide to view the many species who call this water their home at different times of the year.

The car park is free and we can walk or drive from there to the cafe.

name: Midsummer Night's Dream at The Roman Theatre, St. Albans
description:
The OVO theatre company always has a very different spin on Shakespeare ... this time the classic play is set in the 1970s disco period with iconic music to enjoy. The Roman Theatre is a wonderful open-air venue set in an ancient auditorium outside St. Albans. The cost of tickets is £24.50 which includes their £1 commission. Once you have RSVPed. please pay by bank transfer -

Martin Jones
Sort code:[masked]
Account number:[masked].
Please send a message when you have paid. Let me know if you wish to pay by another method.

OVO’s brand new musical Shakespeare transports audiences to the glittering, hustling, hip swivelling age of disco.
In the beige 1970s in a down at heel working men’s club somewhere in the north of England, barman Nick Bottom dreams of a music career. The only problem is, he can’t sing. Meanwhile, Mia, Helen, Dean and Andy are drinking, snogging, arguing and fighting - much to the disapproval of their parents. But then... It all gets a bit messy. A mystical figure appears. And they are all transported to a rather different sort of club. Once there they find themselves wrapped in the dream-like arms of an enchanted fun palace where games of fantasy and love ensue. Where a new dance craze called disco is like a religion, and its masters are like gods. But will Nick discover his voice? Will Mia, Andy, Helen and Dean be reconciled? And will some of the disco world’s magic rub off on the uneventful lives they left behind?
This promises to be The Dream as you’ve never seen it before – featuring some of the best dance music ever produced, from the likes of Abba, Gloria Gaynor, Bee Gees, Donna Summer, The Jacksons and many more. So come and join our live band at the Midsummer Party. If you enjoyed our 80s rock festival Merry Wives of Windsor, and our As You Like It set in the summer of love, then this is the show for you.

Parking is tricky so it's best to get there as soon as possible. It's possible to park in local streets but these are likely to fill up quickly.

name: Bank holiday walk and lunch: Aldbury, Canal, Pitstone Hill and Ashridge.
description:
This is a 7.1 mile walk and is mainly flat with an uphill rise to the Ashridge woods. We begin in the picturesque village of Aldbury and set off towards Tring Station and on to the Grand Union Canal. We take a stroll through pathways, fields and woods before picking up the Ridgeway and passing through the Aldbury Nowers nature reserve. Through an enclosed pathway, we follow the ridge overlooking the Pitstone reservoir and then head to Pitstone Hill where there is a magnificent view of the surrounding area. An uphill climb takes us up to the Ashridge woods before descending through fields. A ½ mile walk along a country road brings us back to the village.

There is some parking in front of the pub but there is much more space along Trooper Road which is opposite Stocks Road. The full ddress for the pub is Greyhound Inn, Stocks Rd, Aldbury, Tring HP23 5RT.

Tables have been booked at the Greyhound Inn to enable us to relax and have food and drinks after the walk.

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. description:

We walk across the ridge to Gallows Hill then descend to fields and through The Coombe where we walk through dense woodland. There is a steep rise before coming out of the woods and along a farm lane to re-enter Ashridge woods. A 30 minute walk back along Duncombe Terrace to finish back at the visitor centre where we can have some refreshments at the cafe.

The address for the Ashridge visitor centre is Moneybury Hill, Ringshall, Berkhamsted HP4 1LX but be wary of SatNav directions which could lead you astray. The visitor centre is well signposted from the B4506.

Tring Theatre Company are excited to perform an all-new adaptation of Dad’s Army. Featuring two episodes that have never been brought to the stage before.

In Turkey Dinner, Jones’ section accidently shoots a turkey whilst on patrol and Mainwaring insists they compensate the owner. The owner cannot be found, so they organise a Christmas dinner for the old age pensioners of Walmington.

In Never Too Old (the final episode of the series), Jones surprises the platoon by announcing he’s going to marry Mrs Fox. The platoon carries on, whilst plans for his big day get underway. Mrs Fox asks Mainwaring back to her flat and asks him for a favour.

The performance begins at 7.30pm but we can meet up for a chat and a drink in the bar area at 7pm. There is ample parking at the theatre.

Rex Review:
Although Major William Martin’s body washed up on the southern Spanish coast in 1943, the man himself never actually existed. He was, in fact, a figment of a team of British Intelligence officers’ imagination and part of what became known as one of the greatest deception operations in military history: Operation Mincemeat. Based on Ben Macintyre’s book of the same name, here John Madden (previously known for Shakespeare in Love and The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel films) tensely traces Operation Mincemeat from conception to completion.
When Ewen Montagu KC (Colin Firth) announces his retirement the night before his wife and children depart for America without him, his brother Ivor (Mark Gatiss) suspects he has a new, covert occupation lined up. Indeed, Ewen has been hired by British Intelligence to assist with a ploy to deceive the Nazis of the location of an impending invasion. With family-friend Hester Leggett (Penelope Wilton), the resourceful Jean Leslie (Kelly Macdonald) and meticulous Charles Cholmondeley by Ewan’s side it seems to be a winning combination. That is until conflicts of personal affections and egos, combined with pressure from their superiors Admiral John Godfrey (Jason Isaacs) and Churchill (Simon Russell Beale), threaten the success of their plan.

Fading Hollywood action hero Jefferson Steele arrives in England to play King Lear in Stratford – only to find that this is not the birthplace of the Bard, but a sleepy Suffolk village. The cast are amateurs trying to save their theatre from developers. Jefferson’s ego, vanity and insecurity are tested to the limit by the enthusiastic am-dram thespians. As acting worlds collide and Jefferson’s career implodes, he discovers some truths about himself.
The Stage said that ‘the acerbic wit of Ian Hislop and Nick Newman metamorphoses into some hugely funny one-liners verging on farce in the best possible way’. The Mail on Sunday gave the show four stars, saying it was ‘deliciously stuffed with Shakespeare… a laugh-a-minute’.

There is a very large car park at Westminster Lodge which is on the same site as the theatre.

Rex Review:
Following on from superb psychological horrors The Witch and The Lighthouse, Robert Eggers yet again delivers violent, gripping and haunting levels of immersion in one of the most unforgettable films of the year.
Starring Alexander Skarsgård, Eggers’ Viking revenge epic is a ferocious and stunning work of art. Based on the same Scandinavian folk tale that inspired Shakespeare’s Hamlet, the bloody story follows Amleth, a vengeful 10th century Viking prince who sets out on a quest to kill the man who murdered his father and enslaved his mother, Queen Gudrun (Nicole Kidman). Along the way he meets a mysterious woman, Olga (Anya Taylor-Joy), with whom he forms the first real human connection since his childhood.
Eggers, who co-wrote the screenplay with Icelandic poet and novelist Sjón, explores basic, primal human nature. From female rage to paternal love there is a brutal and dazzling attention to detail, all played out against the beautiful backdrops of the Nordic islands.

If Morbius marked a dismal testament to the present state of Hollywood blockbuster filmmaking, The Northman is every bit the antidote. Challenging, engaging and laced with raw emotion, it’s simply event cinema at its finest.

name: Berk worms 2022 🐛 BookClub: Travel Writing
description:
For May 2022, we have selected to read a book that is travel writing. The book we have selected is: ‘ Travels with a Tangerine: A journey in the footnotes of Ibn Battutah’ by Tim Mackintosh-Smith. The book was first published in 2001 and the length runs at approximately 368 pages and it is available in most formats, including paperback. The kindle edition is £3.99.

About the book:

Ibn Battutah set out in 1325 from his native Tangier on the pilgrimage to Mecca. By the time he returned twenty-nine years later, he had visited most of the known world, travelling three times the distance Marco Polo covered. Spiritual backpacker, social climber, temporary hermit and failed ambassador, he braved brigands, blisters and his own prejudices. The outcome was a monumental travel classic.

Captivated by this indefatigable man, award-winning travel writer Tim Mackintosh-Smith set out on his own eventful journey, retracing the Moroccan's eccentric trip from Tangier to Constantinople. Tim proves himself a perfect companion to this distant traveller, and the result is an amazing blend of personalities, history and contemporary observation.

About the Author:

Tim Mackintosh-Smith's first book, YEMEN: TRAVELS IN DICTIONARY LAND won the 1998 Thomas Cook/Daily Telegraph Travel Book Award and is now regarded as a classic of Arabian description. His books on Ibn Battutah's adventures in the old Islamic world and in India have all received huge critical acclaim. LANDFALLS was awarded the Oldie Best Travel Award in 2010 and the Ibn Battutah Prize of Honour by the Arab Centre for Geographical Literature. His journeys in search of Ibn Battutah have also been turned into a major BBC television series. For the past twenty-five years his home has been the Yemeni capital San'a, where he lives in a tower-house on top of the ancient Sabaean city and next door to the modern donkey market. You can find out more about him at www.mackintosh-smith.com

__________________________________

Critical views:

'A brilliant, erudite and entertaining literary coup' ― Time

'Battutah couldn't enjoy a better champion . . . This is a considerable book, mind-broadening, not only in the way that it revives the history of a remarkable traveller, but also for its representation of modern Islam as tolerant, hospitable, humorous and cultured' ― The Times

'Sometimes, as [Mackintosh-Smith] travels from Cairo to the Crimea, across deserts, into assassins' strongholds, it seems that Ibn Battutah is just a swish of a robe ahead' ― Independent

READING AHEAD WITH THE BERK WORMS🐛

14 June: Historical Fiction: we are reading The Burning Chambers by Kate Mosse.
12 July: thriller to be selected in May’s meet up
09 August: Dystopian
13 September: history
11 October: psychological
08 November: 19th Century Literature
13 December: Memoirs

Happy reading, Cazza

name: Midweek walk: Berkhamsted, Frithsden Beeches and Ashridge
description:
In my absence, this walk will be led by Diana so please be sure to offer your support and gratitude. The 5.8 mile walk takes in some great views of the urban landscape, valleys and woodland to the north of the historic town of Berkhamsted. Wide, field-edge paths and woodland paths give plenty of space. A relatively easy style-free walk on level paths with about 10 gates and just two short uphill sections. We pass through the Alpine Meadow, the woodland of Frithsden beeches, along Berkhamsted golf course and then skirt around the castle. The walk will take in the historical sites of the World War I trenches and Berkhamsted Castle. There may be a short detour (time and weather permitting) to visit the Berkhamsted Castle visitor centre and learn a bit of history. After the walk we can select one of the many cafes in the town centre.

The car park is accessed by Broadwater. Take Lower Kings Road over the canal, turn left into Broadwater and follow the windy road past Berkhamsted Football Club. Please note that there are no public toilets in the car park but it is possible to use the nearby Waitrose facilities. The walk should take 2.5 hours.

Please note that this walk is not led by a qualified leader and, as such, isn't covered by insurance. Be sure to wear suitable boots and clothing. The organiser cannot be held responsible for any injuries, however caused. Members are expected to take responsibility for their own preparation and safety including adequate fluids, weather protection and a snack. Please be sure to make me aware if you have any medical conditions.

Dogs are welcome as always but please be mindful to keep them on leads for roads and around other animals.

If you are unable to attend please be sure to change your RSVP otherwise our departure will be delayed.

This walk will go ahead with the recent advice by the government that groups of up to 30 are able to meet outdoors from 17th May.

The threat from the virus is very low, especially outdoors, but it is still with us and we should still keep aware of the threat and take the usual precautions, such as considering your own health before attending and social distancing.

It is essential that we continue to operate the walks in a covid-secure way so please only RSVP if you agree to the following:
1. Only attend the walks if you have no symptoms or reason to believe you have been exposed to the virus
2. Only attend the walks if you, or anyone you are a carer for, are not in the vulnerable category
3. Greet people without physical contact
4. Walk at a safe distance from others on the walk at least 2 meters apart.

Track and trace requirements

It is fairly easy for us to operate our own ‘track and trace’ system. If anyone develops symptoms within 2 days after a walk please contact the walk leader as soon as possible so he/she can put contact tracing into operation by alerting other members via Meetup messages. Having taken a Covid test, you should then contact the walk leader who can then inform others of the result.

name: Weekend Walk: Tring reservoirs and the Grand Union Canal
description:
This walk is intended mainly for group members who can't usually make the weekday walks, but obviously everyone is welcome.
It starts in the centre of Tring and circum-navigates the three reservoirs (Tringford, Startops End, and Marsworth), with lovely views of the lakes, before heading SE along the Grand Union Canal. The reservoirs are always a good spot to see birds, so I recommend bringing a pair of binoculars for those so inclined.
The latter part of the walk includes a couple of options. For the slightly more energetic, we head down the canal past Bulbourne, to the bridge next to Tring Station, then return to the town via Station Rd, which takes us past the Pendley Manor Hotel.
Alternatively, stop at the Bulbourne bridge, and have a drink or early lunch (served from 12 noon) at the Grand Junction pub, now fully renovated. If the weather's nice, it's delightful to sit in the garden overlooking the canal. After a break, you can stroll back into town via Marshcroft Lane - actually the difference in distance is probably less than a mile.
The walk is around 9.5 kms, call it a little over 6 miles, and since we are beside the lakes and the canal, it is nearly all flat. The footpaths around the lakes are mostly graded gravel, but the canal towpath can be quite muddy if there has been a lot of rain.

After the walk we can select one of the many cafes in the town centre.

Park at The Forge car park, on Tring High St. The walk should take about 2.5 hours, not counting time out at the Grand Junction!

description:

The vineyard grows 8 varieties of grape including Bacchus, Chardonnay, Huxelrebe, Dornfelder and Pinot Noir and produces white, rosé, red and sparkling wines which frequently win medals in Regional, National and International competitions as well as an English Brandy, one of England's first!

Arrive around 7:45pm for a glass of wine before we start promptly at 8pm. There will be a cheese and biscuit buffet half way through.

The venue is Buckland Village Hall, New Road, Buckland, HP22 5JB near Tring and Aston Clinton.

If you wish to join Aston Wine Club, the joining fee is £20 which includes two tasting glasses, and then the tasting fee per meeting is £15 and you will also be able to attend any special members' only events.

group.name: The Constant Readers Book Club: All Things Stephen King

description:
In the first of King's co-written novels we have encountered at book club we travel to the Territories for some epic fantasy!

The discussion will be online and I'll post the link to the meeting on the day. The meeting will probably last about 2-3 hours including drinks breaks.

Please look out for any great second hand versions, there are a load of great covers out there - do post them on here and/or bring them along to the meeting!

Book blurb follows:
Twelve-year-old Jack Sawyer embarks on an epic quest--a walk from the seacoast of New Hampshire to the California coast--to find the talisman that will save his dying mother's life. Jack's journey takes him into the Territories, a parallel medieval universe, where most people from his own universe have analogs called "twinners." The queen of the Territories, Jack's mother's twinner, is also dying.

Book blurb follows:
Twelve-year-old Jack Sawyer embarks on an epic quest--a walk from the seacoast of New Hampshire to the California coast--to find the talisman that will save his dying mother's life. Jack's journey takes him into the Territories, a parallel medieval universe, where most people from his own universe have analogs called "twinners." The queen of the Territories, Jack's mother's twinner, is also dying.

Book blurb follows:
Shawshank: In 1947 Portland, Maine, banker Andy Dufresne is convicted of murdering his wife and her lover and is sentenced to two consecutive life sentences at the Shawshank State Prison. He is befriended by Ellis "Red" Redding, an inmate and prison contraband smuggler serving a life sentence.
The Body: It's 1960 in the fictional town of Castle Rock, Maine. Ray Brower, a boy from a nearby town, has disappeared, and twelve-year-old Gordie Lachance and his three friends set out on a quest to find his body along the railroad tracks.

name: Christine (Online Meetup)

group.name: The Constant Readers Book Club: All Things Stephen King

description:
Back to the supernatural and a King classic - oh, how he loves his possessed motor vehicles! Though we won't specifically be discussing it, I would also recommend the John Carpenter film adaptation.

The discussion will be online and I'll post the link to the meeting on the day. The meeting will probably last about 2-3 hours including drinks breaks.

Please look out for any great second hand versions, there are a load of great covers out there - do post them on here and/or bring them along to the meeting!

Book blurb follows:
It’s love at first sight for high school student Arnie Cunningham when he and his best friend Dennis Guilder spot the dilapidated 1958 red-and-white Plymouth Fury for sale—dubbed “Christine” by its original cantankerous owner—rusting away on a front lawn of their suburban Pennsylvania neighborhood. Dennis knows that Arnie’s never had much luck in the looks or popularity department, or really taken an interest in owning a car . . . but Christine quickly changes all that. Arnie suddenly has the newfound confidence to stick up for himself, going as far as dating the most beautiful girl at Libertyville High—transfer student Leigh Cabot—even as a mysteriously restored Christine systematically and terrifyingly consumes every aspect of Arnie’s life. Dennis and Leigh soon realize that they must uncover the awful truth behind a car with a horrifying and murderous history. Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned, and heaven help anyone who gets in Christine’s way…

Book Blurb follows:
Following Roland Deschain's confrontation with the man in black, the gunslinger descends from the Cyclopean Mountains to the Western Sea, where he is attacked by lobstrosities from the ocean. As his health wanes, he must travel the shoreline in search of three doors that will allow him access to Keystone Earth, from where he encounters people – including the drug-addict Eddie Dean, the schizophrenic Susannah Holmes, and the psychopathic Jack Mort – who are tied to his journey to the Dark Tower.

Book Blurb follows:
There is a strange club in New York where men tell each other stories. The years pass but no one looks any older. One night a doctor tells the story of a young woman who gives birth to a baby in the most horrible way! Evil psychic powers, obsession and the supernatural in the most ordinary, everyday places. A spine-chiller from the master of horror.

name: Danse Macabre (Second Session)

group.name: The Constant Readers Book Club: All Things Stephen King

description:
The discussion will be online and I'll post the link to the meeting on the day. The meeting will probably last about 2 hours with a break around half time.

Please look out for any great second hand versions, there are a load of great covers out there - do post them on here and/or bring them along to the meeting! Some newer versions include an extra essay called "What's Scary?"

Book Blurb follows:
Before he gave us the “one of a kind classic” (The Wall Street Journal) memoir On Writing, Stephen King wrote a nonfiction masterpiece in Danse Macabre, “one of the best books on American popular culture” (Philadelphia Inquirer).
From the author of dozens of #1 New York Times bestsellers and the creator of many unforgettable movies comes a vivid, intelligent, and nostalgic journey through three decades of horror as experienced through the eyes of the most popular writer in the genre. In 1981, years before he sat down to tackle On Writing, Stephen King decided to address the topic of what makes horror horrifying and what makes terror terrifying. Here, in ten brilliantly written chapters, King delivers one colorful observation after another about the great stories, books, and films that comprise the horror genre—from Frankenstein and Dracula to The Exorcist, The Twilight Zone, and Earth vs. The Flying Saucers.
With the insight and good humor his fans appreciated in On Writing, Danse Macabre is an enjoyably entertaining tour through Stephen King’s beloved world of horror.

name: Private hot yoga session for hot ladies

group.name: Ladies Who Brunch ...and pretty much do everything else too

description:
This is a photo of me. Doing yoga. Casual. This is how I like to wake up. 5am? No problem. I just leap out of bed and do a headstand. Well, a sort of headstand. A headstand not on my head, but on my arms. I'm also this thin, so that's cool. I'm thin and do headstands not on my head but my arms.
...I'm, of course, joking. It's been a long day and I'm delirious. But if this is a picture of you, please do not attend this workshop. You are not invited.

What is hot yoga anyway?
It’s like regular yoga — but hotter.
Hot yoga just means doing yoga in a room that’s heated to an above-average temp, typically between 80 to 100°F (26 to 38°C). It can include any number of poses and music to get your practice flowing. To be honest, I have no idea, but I've wanted to do it forever and the lovely people at Yoga TW12 said we could have our own private class.

What are the benefits of hot yoga?

After a quick bit of Googling, I discovered hot yoga comes with with many glorious benefits:

1. Bendy goodness
It’s no secret that warmed-up muscles just stretch better. Bending and stretching in hotter temps is safer, and it might make those tough poses a little easier to pull off.

2. Reduce stress
When life keeps piling on the BS, why not try sweating it out?
In a 2018 study of physically inactive, stressed adults, a 16-week hot yoga program reduced the participants’ stress levels significantly. Fingers crossed for the same improvements in one hour.

3. Burn calories
Hot yoga is a solid way to burn calories. A 2014 study found that, on average, women burned 330 calories and men burned 460 calories in a 90-minute Bikram sesh. The hotter temp makes your body work harder than usual. So even if a hot yoga class is less intense than the standard Bikram fare, you’ll still burn more calories than you would in traditional yoga.

4. Help your cardiovascular health
The extra heat and humidity make yoga poses more challenging for your heart — a bonus if you want to kick your cardiovascular health up a notch. A 2014 study found that one hot yoga session gets the heart pumping at the same rate as a brisk walk of 3.5 miles per hour.

5. Strengthen your bones
Women are at especially high risk for osteoporosis. In a 2014 study, premenopausal women who practised Bikram yoga over a 5-year period had increased bone density in their lower back, hips, and neck. Very cool.

6. Lower your blood sugar
If you’re at risk for type 2 diabetes, you might reap extra benefits from hot yoga. To be clear: any type of exercise will help reduce glucose levels in your bloodstream. But a 2013 study found that a short-term hot yoga program boosted glucose tolerance especially well in older adults with obesity.

7. Helps with relaxation and mood
Yoga originated in ancient India, where the practice was much more than physical exercise — it had a meditative and spiritual purpose. Today, it’s still well-known for its relaxation and mood-boosting benefits. A 2017 review of 23 studies also concluded that yoga was an effective way to reduce symptoms of depression.

8. Nourish your skin and immune system
Don’t let getting soaked by your own perspiration deter you from turning up the heat (or turning up). Sweating in a hot environment can boost your circulation, which helps your immune system work its best. It also can help nourish your skin from the inside out, giving you a rosy glow. Who needs makeup? Not us.

PLEASE NOTE:
You will get sweaty. We do not care that you are sweaty.
(There is a shower on the premises, but will be a long queue if we all have one).

THINGS TO BRING:
The studio recommends bringing a towel for your mat and a towel if you'd like a shower.

TIMINGS:
11.00: Coffee/food pre-yoga. They say you should leave an hour between eating and a session, so this should give us a bit of time to eat, chat and then get to work.
13:00 - 14:00: Yoga session
14:01: Dash home a sweaty mess

LOCATION(s):
Pre-coffee & food (11am): Bentons, 118d High St, Hampton Hill, Hampton TW12 1NT
Yoga (1pm): Yoga TW12, 44 High St, Hampton Hill, Hampton TW12 1PD, UK.
9 min walk / 5 min bus from Fulwell Station.
Lots of bus options locally.
Free on-street parking on Sundays and the car park opposite The Beech House.

COSTS:
£11 for the session + £3 toward meetup costs
Please ping me all funds to reserve your space (message me for bank details).
N.b. once paid, this is non-refundable as I need to pay a deposit. But if you need to cancel and you can find someone to take your place then that's absolutely fine - please organise transfers between you.

Looking forward to seeing you!

I’ve increased the numbers as some of you have said you’d like to bring friends, so the more the merrier! 🎉

name: Pre-Christmas Christmas Cocktails & Pizza in Richmond!

group.name: Ladies Who Brunch ...and pretty much do everything else too

description:
There’s pizza, there’s prosecco, there's the magic of Christmas in November – what more could a girl want?? Nothing. That's right. (Except to spend it surrounded by gorgeous gal pals, of course).

I've persuaded Franco Manca in Richmond to let us take over their private room downstairs. £25 each and that will get the table piled high with pizzas, a cocktail on arrival and wine & prosecco to flow until the tab runs out. (After that point, feel free to top up any additional drinks yourselves). I'm hoping to get some Christmas games going too, to really get us in the spirit. We need 15 people minimum to reserve the private room.

COST:
£25 - includes a selection of pizzas to share, one cocktail on arrival and wine/prosecco until the tab runs out. (At that point please feel free to purchase additional food/drinks as you like - although I think that should more than cover it).

WOMEN SUPPORTING WOMEN:
Any funds leftover will be shared between meetup's cost to run this group (£120) and Solace Women's Aid. We are unbelievably lucky that, for us, the festive season is a time of togetherness and celebration, but Christmas also sees a surge in calls made from women seeking support for domestic abuse, and families needing refuge. Last year, calls to domestic abuse charity, Solace Women’s Aid increased by 77% following the Christmas period. A £10 donation to the charity will support a ‘box of fundamentals’. These boxes, given to each woman who arrives at Solace, include items like shampoo, soap and sanitary products, and are essential in offering women support and protection during the first night’s stay at a refuge. If you'd like to support with an additional donation for the charity, please let me know and I would be delighted to include this. Or you can find out more and donate here: https://www.solacewomensaid.org/news/solace-womens-aid-christmas-campaign-invites-support-women-who-arrive-refuges-nothing

HOW TO BOOK:
As usual, space is limited and given on a first-paid-first-reserved basis.
Once you're on the list ping me a message and I'll send you the bank details to reserve your spot. Then check out the menu (link below) and send me your preferences of:
1. pizza
2. welcome cocktail (Aperol Spritz / Negroni / Negroni sbagliato / Gin & Tonic / wine / prosecco)
3. wine/prosecco

https://www.francomanca.co.uk/menu/

ADDRESS:
(Please note, this is an indoor reservation)
Franco Manca
8 Red Lion Street,
Richmond Upon Thames,
TW9 1RW

GETTING THERE:
Plenty of public transport options (please google/citymapper your route). For non-drinkers who might drive, there are a few paid parking options in Richmond town centre - 10 Bridge Street & 5 Friars Lane.

NEW MEMBERS:
This is a wonderful opportunity to meet amazing women. If you've not been to any of our meetups before, please don't be nervous - just come along and enjoy.

Really looking forward to seeing you all. Any questions, let me know. Love,

Charlie Xx

name: Coffee Catchup and Beginners Golf @ Hersham Golf Club

group.name: Ladies Who Brunch ...and pretty much do everything else too

description:
Hi All!! Lovely Charlie has passed me the reigns to organise a golf session for us all so here it goes...

...Ever felt like trying your hand at something new? I’m always looking for lovely ladies to join me on the golf course, at the driving range or even just at the clubhouse for a coffee!

So this is the perfect opportunity to give golf a try with a group of lovely women and enjoy a pre-golf lesson coffee or post-lesson drink, depending on how it goes!. If you have played before and don’t feel like you need the golf lesson (aimed at beginners) please come along for the coffee and enjoy the driving range on your own time! But let me know so I can manage the group numbers so we don't go over the 15 person limit for the lesson.

Cost:
The lesson will be aimed at beginners and will be £15pp which needs to be pre-paid to reserve your spot (and also is a really good price for group lessons in Surrey, I've heard some places charging up to £35pp for group lessons!). It will be taught by my coach who I’ve been working with for 4 years - he’s very good and super nice. Any drinks/food before or after the lesson you can buy at the venue on the day.

Duration:
The session will be 1h30 to ensure everyone gets some direct coaching time with Alex and practice after.

When:
Saturday 13th November.
Please come at 10:30am for a coffee meetup beforehand, followed by the coached lesson starting at 11:30am.

Location:
We will be doing it at Hersham Golf Club, which is super easy access for those who don’t have a car as the train station is 6 min walk to the golf club. There is also plenty of car parking at the club for those driving.

Address:
Assher Rd, Hersham, Walton-on-Thames KT12 4RA (sometimes this takes sat navs to a strange place, so just aim for Hersham Railway Station and you’ll see the signposts).

How to book:
Space is limited to 16 people and given on a first-paid-first-reserved basis. Once you're on the list I'll send you a message with the bank details to reserve your spot.

Really looking forward to seeing you all there, it might not be the most glorious golf weather in November… but there are covered bays - thank goodness!

Also, if you do really like golf or find you enjoy the event so much you want to do it regularly visit the Meetup page below which I just started for women's golf - first event is 27th October!
https://www.meetup.com/skratch-women-golf-meetup-group/?_ga=2.63848943.158602029.1634496087-569628007.1632061464

Cal xx

name: Brunch and Catch Up

group.name: Ladies Who Brunch ...and pretty much do everything else too
